rules.name: Establish the Current Conditions
rules.description: In a change proposal, you first want to establish the current conditions. These are the present conditions in need of change. Another common name for the current conditions is the status quo.

children.name: What is the thing you propose to change?
children.description:
How is this expectation met in English sentences?

You meet it by describing the thing you propose to change neutrally.

Consider a writer who is a member of their college's rowing club. The writer can think of various neutral things to say about club. Neutrally, the rowing club has been in existence for decades, has at any time about twenty members, and recruits students from across campus.

topics.prompt: List the words and phrases that describe the thing you want to change.

children.examples:
The rowing club at our university was founded in 1985 and takes in studentss from many majors across campus.

The technical interview process is something almost all computer science majors go through when they graduate.

This generation of college students is well-known to be actively involved in community service but the university can be slow to acknowleddge this.

Most campus eateries provide allergen sheets that list the allergens in their foods but some don't.
children.cv_description: By meeting this expectation, you make your writing more considerate. Your reader needs a neutral picture of what's going on now as a baseline for helping the reader understand why you are invested in the status quo and why you want to change it. By supporting the reader's need for this neutral picture before you complicate it, your text is considerate.

children.name: What's good happening now that makes this change worth investing in?
children.description:
How is this expectation met in English sentences?

You meet it by describing the positive aspects of the current state (what's working?) to establish the fact that this change is a worthwhile investment.

Let's return to our rower who wants their college to upgrade rowing from a club sport to a varsity sport. You want to show what makes investment in that upgrade worthwhile.

What record of success has the rowing club shown that makes this upgrade both important and timely? Words and phrases that help answer this question might be “recruits committed individuals”, “has won many trophies in community competition”, and “respresents some of the university's best scholar-athletes”.

topics.lemma: Positive Aspects of the Current State
topics.prompt: List the words and phrases that describe what are working well now?

children.examples:
The rowing club has boasted many top student athletes over the years.

Today's students are greatly interested in learning everything they can about personal finance.

Vegan students have waiting patiently for the uiversity to create an all-vegan eatery.

Even students who pride themsevles on making it to class consistently and on-time are having more trouble doing so with the lack of crossing lanes.
children.cv_description: By meeting this expectation, you show your reader that the status quo contains positive features only worth preserving but worth investing in further. Your ability to argue for why the time is right for change enhances your crediblity to steward the status quo into the future and that in turn makes your writing more compelliing. In addition, to comprehend your proposal, your reader needs a clear picture of what's right about the current conditions to understand why the status quo deserves additional investment. Your support of the reader's comprehension and informed judgment makes you a considerate writer.

children.name: What's bad happening now that makes this change necessary? (gaps)
children.description:
How is this expectation met in English sentences?

You meet it by describing the problems associated with the thing you want to change, and why these problems make the proposed change ncessary.

Let's return to our rower who wants their college to upgrade rowing from a club sport to a varsity sport. You will want to list negative information about the status of the rowing club that makes change seem necessary.

Negative words and phrases associated with the current conditions might be that, because rowing remains only a club and not a varsity sport, the college “loses top recruits to other schools while the rowers are left to rely on ”outdated rowing equipment“, and ”inadequate“ medical coverage compared to the coverage extended to the members of the varsity sports.

topics.prompt: List the words and phrases that describe the problems associated with the thing you propose to change, and why these problems make the proposed change necessary

children.examples:
The rowing club on this campus is imperiled because it has not been granted status as a variety sport.

The current tests that many technology companies give to evalulate student applicant programming skills are unfair and invalid meausres of what professional programmers need to do on the job.

A street that hundreds of students cross per hour to get to their classes lacks crosswalks, stop signs, and traffic lights, and is a prsent danger to students.

Our campus currently has no eatery that satisfies the nutritional requirements of vegans.

There is a dearth of reporters on the campus newspaper primarily due to apathy.
children.cv_description: By creating easily identifiable and troubling gap sentences, you show your crediblity to motivate change and you show your considerateness to readers to prepare them to comprehend the change you propose.

rules.name: Present Your Change Proposal
rules.description: After you have established the current conditions, you are ready to present your proposal for change.

children.name: What concrete change(s) do you propose?
children.description:
How is this expectation met in English sentences?

You meet it by describing the specific changes you propose.

Let's return to our rower who wants to make rowing a varsity sport on campus. The change proposed is the topic cluster “make rowing a varsity sport” or simply “varsity sport”. Sentences containing that topic, and variations, should recur consistently throughout the change proposal, and with each recurrence, the reader will take it for the proposed solution.

topics.prompt: List all the words and phrases associated with the change you propose.

children.examples:
Rowing needs to be turned into a varsity sport.

Companies need fairer ways to test the ability of programmers.

The university needs to place a stop sign and crosswalk at this dangerous intersection.

Dining services on campus should label all foods sold with nutritional and allergenic information.
children.cv_description: By meeting this expectation, you make it easy for your reader to pick out your proposed change and this makes your text a considerate text.

children.name: How does your proposal fill the gaps?
children.description:
How is this expectation met in English sentences?

You meet it by including words and phrases that spell out the improvements that will result from putting your proposed change into effect.

Consider our rowing example where the proposed change is to upgrade rowing from a club sport to a varsity sport. Here the phrase “varsity sport” would often be close to the proposed changes.

Phrases associated with improvements include positive languages.

  • “Making rowing a varsity sport will help recruit the best rowers graduating from high school”
  • “As a varsity sport, rowing will put our rowing team on the map”
  • “Upgrading rowing to a varsity sport will grow our population of student athletes”

topics.prompt: List the words and phrases associated with the improvements your proposal will bring about.

children.examples:
Making rowing a varsity sport will double our population of student athletes.

By making company tests for hiring programmers open book and focused on practical problems, companies will make better hiriing decisions and students coming out of school will be treated more fairly.

Placing a stop sign and crosswalk on Elm and Fifth will improve the safety of students who rely on that intersection to get to classes. It will also send the message that the university makes student safety a top priority.

Creating an eatery on campus that is entirely vegan will accommodate the increasing number of students who are vegan or who want to explore a vegan lifestyle. It will also help recruit students from high school who are vegan or want to try it in their college years.

By developing a policy on campus free speech that respects free speech as a constitutional right while upholding the university's values of respect and dignity for all is important for maintaining a healthy campus climate, encouraging open inquiry, and better coping with hate speech.
children.cv_description: By crafting sentences that meet this expectation, you show you can credibly (from a problem-solving point of view) and compellingly (from a reader point of view) link your proposed change to tangible advantages.

children.name: How does your proposal affirm the values of your target audience?
children.description:
How Is this expectation met in English sentences?

You meet it by identifying the values you and your target audience share, and showing how putting your proposal into effect advances those values.

topics.prompt: List the positive values you and your target audience share.

children.examples:
The university has an overriding interest to recruit the best student-athletes graduating from high school. It happens that, across all sports, rowing attracts some of the best student athletes.

The university has a significant interest in the safety of students. And this is why making campus intersections safe is such a compelling interest.

Campus leaders undertand that while students are here to acquire knowledge, their health and nutritional well-being are also very important.

Tech companies hiring programmers out of college need students who can solve practical programming problems. If they are to meet this need, they need to make sure they screen for applicants with this practical programming sense.
children.cv_description: By linking the values of your change proposal to the deepest values of your target audience, you make your text compelling.

rules.name: Address The Limitations In Your Proposal
rules.description: In a change proposal, your proposal is bound to have some limitations and you need to acknowledge them.

children.name: What are the limitations of your proposal?
children.description:
How is this expectation met in English sentences?

You meet it by being upfront and transparent about the limitations in your proposal, the aspects of your proposal that might make your target audience reject it despite its merits.

topics.prompt: Indicate the words and phrases that reference the scale-downs, compromises, and adjustments you would be willing to make if your proposal can't be accepted because certain limitations seem impassable.

children.examples:
I acknowlege that my proposal comes with an expensive price tag.

After talking to unversity officials, I learned that we can get a vegan eatery, but only if we eliminate an existing eatery, and that may be a hard pill to swallow.

I recognize that my proposal to expand greek life on campus is a low priority for the administration.

A bike-sharing program for campus, which I propose, was tried a few years ago and it failed. So you are right to be skeptical about it.
children.cv_description: Let's return to our rower who wants their college to upgrade rowing to a varsity sport. This is an appealing solution for the rowing club. But it is also an expensive solution. And the university has many sports to support! Proposal writers lose credibility when they fail to address the limitations in their proposal. They also show lapses of ethical balance if they come across as thinking that the strengths of their proposal should count more than the weaknesses. They also show a lapse of ethical and considerate thinking if they leave it to their target audience to find the weak links. Their need to assist their audience in seeing them.
children.parent: Address The Limitations In Your Proposal

children.name: How do you plan to address (mitigate) these limitations?
children.description:
How is this expectation met in English sentences?

You meet this expectation by including the adjustments or refinements you would be willing to make if you believe the limitations in your proposal might be deadbreakers. Even as you indicate what you would be willing to pull back on, make sure to continue to emphasize the positive benefits that can still result from these adjustments.

Words and phrases associated with such accommodating language are the following:

  • “Should my full proposal be too big for immediate implementation, we can proceed incrementally.”
  • “If need be, we can reduce the scope of...“

topics.prompt: List the words and phrases that reference the ways you plan to adress the limitations of your proposal.

children.examples:
Making rowing a varsity sport has a range of upfront and hidden costs that we may not be able to afford. If that is the case, we might think of a one-time investment to bring the equipment up to well-recognized standards of performance and safety.

If a traffic light and cross-walk are too expensive for this intersection, we should consider a stop sign or even a "yield to pedestrian" sign. That could still turn out to be very effective.

An eatery dedicated to vegan food may be logistically and financially challenging for the university. If that is the case, I have checked and it would be less challenging to make sure a few existing eateries increase their stock of vegan products.

Completely changing the corporate tests for student programmers may be impossible for many computer companies. However, even if that were the case, there would be no great effort or cost in allowing the tests to be open-book to cut down on meaningless memorization.
children.cv_description: By addressing the limitations of your proposal, you show you are interested in presenting a balanced account (ethical) that is respectful of the reader's potential objections and concerns (considerate). And these impressions in turn contribute to the reader's perception of your credibility as a writer and your willingness to co-construct the proposal with the audience/potential funder to make it compelling.
children.parent: Address The Limitations In Your Proposal
